request_pathways.name: Authorization to Release Protected Health Information

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Patients use a single general-purpose Authorization to Release Protected Health Information form for all records requests, whether for self-access or third-party release.

red_flags: Fee language implies charges for personal-use requests but provides no fee schedule or cost estimate
bright_spots: Email delivery option — uncommon for a critical access hospital
17-category granular record type selection gives patients fine-grained control
"Major Documents for the Last 3 Years" shortcut for patients who don't know exact dates
63 fillable PDF fields enable fully digital form completion

findability.rationale: Level 4: Easy to find with basic navigation — linked from the My Health Records page in 2 clicks from homepage, and surfaced by a simple web search.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 4: Mostly digital with one gap — the form has 63 fillable fields for digital completion, but patients must print and fax/mail to submit since there is no online submission portal.

content_design.rationale: Level 4: Well-organized single-page form with clear section headers and logical flow; minor issues include absent submission instructions, vague fee language, and missing fillable field names for accessibility.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 3: A patient can use the form but it wasn't designed for them — no distinction between patient self-access and third-party release, no reference to HIPAA Right of Access, and 'Personal' is just one of several purpose checkboxes.

compliance.rationale: Level 4: Minor ambiguities but nothing materially impeding — includes revocation rights, non-conditioning language, re-disclosure warning, and right to inspect; fee transparency is the main gap.

overall.summary: Gritman provides a well-constructed, easy-to-find fillable PDF with good compliance language and delivery options, but lacks a dedicated patient access pathway and clear fee disclosure.
